org.schwering.evi.core
Interface IPanel

All Known Implementing Classes:
EnvironmentPanel, HTMLBrowser, LicensePanel, MainConfigurationPanel, ModuleAutoStartConfigurationPanel, ModuleConfigurationPanel, Test
public interface IPanel

Interface for graphical modules.

This interface must be implemented by modules which have a graphical frontend which might be accessible through a tabbar, for example.

This interface does not extend IModule. The reason is that IPanels might (and also must) also be used for configuration dialogs and so on. Nevertheless, the IPanel interface defines a dispose() method same like the IModule interface. Hence, each class that implements IPanel can also implement IModule and vice versa.

To put it in a nutshell: Modules that are inteded to have a GUI should implement both, IModule and IPanel. IPanel is seperate, because it is important for classes that are no modules (more precisely: that are not a module's main-class). An example for this case are module-configuratoin-dialogs.

Version:
$Id: IPanel.java 46 2006-05-09 19:51:27Z schwering $
Author:
Christoph Schwering (mailto:schwering@gmail.com)

Method Summary
 void dispose()
          Should clean up used resources when the panel is shut down.
 javax.swing.Icon getIcon()
          Returns the panel's icon.
 java.awt.Component getPanelInstance()
          Returns a reference to the module instance's GUI part as Component.
 java.lang.String getTitle()
          Returns the panel's title.
 

Method Detail

getPanelInstance

public java.awt.Component getPanelInstance()
Returns a reference to the module instance's GUI part as Component. Each invokation of getPanelInstance must return a reference to the same object. This means that this method must not create a new panel but return just a reference to a once created panel.

If the implementing module extends java.awt.Component (e.g. if it extends javax.swing.JPanel) this method simply might return this.

Returns:
The concrete GUI-part as java.awt.Component.

getTitle

public java.lang.String getTitle()
Returns the panel's title. The title is to be used in the tabbar.

Returns:
The title.

getIcon

public javax.swing.Icon getIcon()
Returns the panel's icon. If the panel should have no icon, this method must return null.

Returns:
The panel's icon or null.
See Also:
ImageIcon

dispose

public void dispose()
Should clean up used resources when the panel is shut down.
This method is also declared in IModule (IModule.dispose()). This makes it easy to write a graphical module that implements both. See the weird explanations at the top.

See Also:
IModule.dispose()
